review.title: Predicting Performance During Tutoring with Models of Recent Performance
review.abstract: In educational technology and learning sciences, there are multiple uses for a predictive model of whether a student will perform a task correctly or not. For example, an intelligent tutoring system may use such a model to estimate whether or not a student has mastered a skill. We analyze the significance of data recency in making such predictions, i.e., asking whether relatively more recent observations of a student's performance matter more than relatively older observations. We develop a new Recent-Performance Factors Analysis model that takes data recency into account. The new model significantly improves predictive accuracy over both existing logistic-regression performance models and over novel baseline models in evaluations on real-world and synthetic datasets. As a secondary contribution, we demonstrate how the widely used cross-validation with 0-1 loss is inferior to AIC and to cross-validation with L1 prediction error loss as a measure of model performance.

metadata.title: Predicting Performance During Tutoring with Models of Recent Performance

sections.text: In educational technology and learning sciences, there are several applications for a predictive model that shows whether a student is performing a task correctly or not. For example, an intelligent tutoring system can use such a model to estimate whether a student is proficient or not. We are analyzing the importance of data recency in making such predictions, i.e. whether relatively recent observations of a student's performance are more important than relatively older observations. We are developing a new model of Recent-Performance Factors Analysis that takes data recency into account. The new model significantly improves predictive accuracy over both existing logistic regression performance models and novel baseline models in evaluating real and synthetic datasets. As a secondary contribution, we show how widespread cross-validation with 0-1 loss is inferior to AIR and a C error in predicting performance as reading.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: A key area of research in educational technology and evaluation is modelling the likelihood that a student will respond correctly to a particular question; this modelling is used to analyze test responses, as in item response theory; in adaptive learning technologies, as in the use of Bayesian Knowledge Tracing (Corbett and Anderson, 1995) in smart tutoring systems; to analyze the areas studied by students, such as studying task transfer (Pavlik et al., 2011); and to understand student behaviors, such as gaming the system (Baker et al., 2004).Our work promotes this field by exploring alternative representations of reciprocity. Intuition is simple: as students practice an ability, we expect their understanding to increase and their performance to improve. Having recently succeeded in a task, it may become more likely that learning has occurred, and such a moment of learning should contribute to our prediction of successful performance.

sections.heading: 2. PRIOR WORK IN PERFORMANCE MODELING
sections.text: In order to predict whether a student will successfully complete a task or not, we should therefore consider some characteristics of the student and the task. There are two main approaches to such modeling in the literature: graphical models, especially Bayesian knowledge tracing, and logistic regression models. A refinement of this approach is Linear Logistic Test Models (LLTM) (Fischer, 1973; de Boeck and Wilson, 2004). These logistic regression models replace the predictor in terms of the student's ability and the difficulty of the task. One refinement of this approach is Linear Logistic Test Models (LLTM) (Fischer, 1973; de Boeck and Wilson, 2004). These logistic regression models replace the predictor in terms of the difficulty of each task with a predictor that shares a basic skill or knowledge component (KC).

sections.heading: 3.1. RECENT-PERFORMANCE FACTORS ANALYSIS
sections.text: The most recent Factor Analysis (R-PFA) focuses on recent history, not the complete practical history of a student (Galyardt and Goldin, 2014). The first intuition behind this model is that it is more likely that the student, having learned a skill, gets the next item right; if he has not learned that skill, a wrong reaction is more likely than a correct one. The second intuition is that the recent practice history with a KC may contain all the necessary information about whether a student has acquired the KC or not. We can associate this idea with a "moment of learning." If a student has been successful with the most recent practice, then a moment of learning is likely to have already occurred. If the most recent attempts have not been successful, then the student has most likely not yet learned the KC.

sections.heading: 3.2. FORMAL MODEL DESCRIPTIONS
sections.text: To comprehensively examine the R-PFA models, we examine a number of alternative models. The notation we use differs from other publications of some models, but we hope that our consistent use of notation in all models will facilitate the comparison. We use the following notation: j KC index, j = 1,.., J i student index, i = 1,.., N t practition opportunity index, t = 1,., Oij Xijt response of students i, on occasion t of KC j, Xijt = {0 if incorrect 1 if correctpijt Probability of a correct response: Pr (Xijt = 1) Tijt count of past opportunities Sijt recency-weighted count of previous success, up to trial t recency-weighted count of previous success, up to trial t Fijt recency-weighted count of previous failure, up to trial t recency-weighted count of a correct response: Pr (Xijt = 1) Tijt count of past failures, up to trial logit weighted count of previous success, up to trial logit sedentary models we examine all the sedentary models, up to sedentary models, up to sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary sedentary.

sections.heading: 4. MODEL APPLICATION TO REAL-WORLD DATA
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1. METHODS
sections.text: We evaluate the number of students described above in the areas of "Learning" and "Learning" (Baker et al., 2011). The data contain the first experiments of 4138 students in terms of their knowledge and skills (KC). The data come from the areas of "Learning" and "Learning" (Assistance).

sections.heading: 4.2. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: This year, it has reached the point where it will be able to retaliate.

sections.heading: 4.3. INTERPRETING THE BEST-PERFORMING MODEL
sections.text: The best overall model for predicting future success from a student's history is R-PFA with 3 parameters for each KC: βj, the "ease" of the KC; ρj, the effects of recent failures with the KC, and δj, the effects of recent successes with the KC. To study model parameters in detail, we must take into account that in a logistic regression model with random effects, estimates of coefficients may not be normally distributed when the data is sparse. This means that it may be inappropriate to use the estimated standard errors to obtain confidence intervals for the parameters. To address this problem, we need to recalibrate the most powerful model using a Markov Chain Monte Carlo algorithm, as implemented in the MCMCglmm package in R (Hadfield, 2010).We are investigating the 95% posterior credible intervals (CI) for each KC parameter (Figure 6), with no limitations estimated on these coefficiencies.

sections.heading: 5. SIMULATION STUDY
sections.text: The purpose of the simulation study was to compare R-PFA with other performance models without the limitations of real data sets. Two features of the wizard dataset examined above make thorough model comparison difficult. Firstly, the scarcity of data in the wizard data (Section 4.) precludes the use of cross-validation for model ranking. Nevertheless, cross-validation is a popular tool model comparison because holding data during model training can help prevent overmatch. Therefore, we compare R-PFA with other models both after cross-validation and after AIC. By using simulated data, we show that AIC is not only an appropriate measure for model selection, but that it is better than cross-validation with the frequently used 0-1 loss function, and it can absorb sparse datas.Secondly, the hold criterion used in the skill build function of aids leads to data being uncontrollable.
